title: 114_s2526
content: The Act titled "Made in America Manufacturing Communities Act of 2016" establishes a program to designate and support manufacturing communities. The Act establishes a program to improve US manufacturing competitiveness by designating and supporting manufacturing communities. The Act allows preferential consideration for financial or technical assistance to members of a manufacturing community consortium if consistent with the economic development strategy and meeting all requirements. The participating agencies for the program include the Department of Agriculture, Commerce, Defense, Education, Energy, Housing and Urban Development, Labor, Transportation, Appalachian Regional Commission, Delta Regional Authority, Environmental Protection Agency, and National Science Foundation. The National Science Foundation and the Small Business Administration are participating agencies in the program. The head of each agency must identify applicable programs for the established program. Multiple members of the same consortium can seek financial or technical assistance from participating agencies. The head of a participating agency can determine preference for financial or technical assistance among members of the same consortium designated as a manufacturing community. The head of a participating agency may require coordination among consortium members applying for financial or technical assistance. Each agency must submit a report on how they will prioritize assistance. The Secretary can provide a Federal point of contact for designated manufacturing communities to access funds and assistance. The program allows consortium members to access Federal funds and technical assistance for economic development purposes. Recipients can use the assistance to support investments. The program provides technical assistance for investments in infrastructure, access to capital, exports, workforce training, energy efficiency, and business incubators to enhance US manufacturing competitiveness. Manufacturing communities are designated through a competitive process involving eligible consortiums representing regions with higher education, private sector, and government entities.
